string-array.name: help_texts
string-array.item: This is a simple audio analyser for Android. It displays sound readings from the microphone as a waveform display, as a frequency spectrum, and as a dB meter. dB levels are relative to the maximum input level of your device.\n\ \n\ Since microphone sensitivity varies between individual devices, let alone models, it\'s impossible to generate accurate sound level readings with this app; so all data should be taken with a pinch of salt. Still, it may be interesting when used to compare sound readings at different locations.

The display shows an analysis of the local acoustic environment. The first section shows a waveform display of the sound picked up by the microphone; this display auto-scales to handle a wide range of sound levels.
\ 
\ Below this a frequency spectrum is displayed. The horizontal scale shows the frequencies displayed; the maximum frequency will depend on the selected sampling rate (see "Settings"). The vertical scale is logarithmic, with a range from -60dB to 0dB. Scale lines are drawn every 10dB.
\ 
\ The third section displays the absolute power level of the sound as received by the device's microphone. This is displayed as decibels (dB) relative to the maximum possible input from the microphone; so 0dB is the maximum the device can register, -10dB is 1/10th of this, -20dB is 1/100th of the max, etc. Each 10 dB multiplies or divides the level by 10.
\ 
\ The power meter also shows peak markers, and a background bar displays a rolling average. The rolling average is also displayed numerically.

The dB Meter shows the noise level, as received by the audio input device, on a logarithmic scale, relative to the maximum audio level the device can process. So the maximum possible input is 0dB; and every 10dB below this represents a reduction by a factor of 10. Hence, -20dB represents a signal 1,000 times as powerful as -50dB.
\ 
\ Since every device's microphone has different sensitivity, there's no way to relate this to actual noise levels.
\ 
\ In practice, this means that:
\ • Full-on noise, totally distorting the input, should register 0dB.
\ • It's very hard to get this in practice. However, traffic noise on the Golden Gate Bridge peaked up to 1dB.
\ • A pure tone at the maximum non-distorting level is about -2.41dB.
\ • A miniscule, almost-not-there signal would be -100dB. However, due to electrical noise inside the device, it's about impossible in practice to get close to this.
\ • With my Droid in a soundproof chamber I got a reading of -68.4dB, so that's a realistic representation of what "very quiet" would register as.
\ 
\ The spectrum analyser also displays a log scale. Here, the output range tends to be more limited, so we display levels down to -60dB from the maximum.

The device's "menu" button pops up a menu containing a number of options:
\ • Settings takes you to the settings screen; see "Settings" below.
\ • Help displays this help.
\ • About displays an about box, with links to the license and the project home page.
\ • Disclaimer re-displays the one-time warning screen.
\ • Exit stops the application.

Audalyzer has a number of user-configurable options in its Settings screen. This screen is reached through the menu, as described under \"Menu\" above. The available settings are detailed in the following sections.
If you would like more information and help with Audalyzer, or if you want to to report a bug, there are some on-line resources which may be of interest, as described in the following sections.

string-array.name: help_prefs_texts
string-array.item:
Sample rate sets the audio sampling rate in samples/second. A higher rate will require more processing power. The frequency range of the spectrum analyser is half the sample rate; this frequency range is displayed alongside the sample rate.
\ 
\ Block size sets the size in samples of the data block processed by the spectrum analyser. A larger block size provides finer frequency resolution but with more delay and more processing power required.
\ 
\ Window function sets the spectrum analyser windowing function. Windowing eliminates spurious frequencies caused by the blocking of the input, at the cost of making peaks a little wider. Blackman-Harris is a good bet.
\ 
\ Decimation reduces the processing workload by only analysing a subset of the input data blocks.
\ 
\ Histogram averaging sets the averaging interval of the spectrum analyser. "None" tells it to display instantaneous values; "Fast" displays the rolling average over a few samples; and "Slow" displays a longer-term rolling average.

Screen orientation determines whether and how the application will switch its display between portrait and landscape:
\ • System default -- the system will determine the orientation based on the task context.
\ • Portrait -- lock to portrait mode.
\ • Landscape -- lock to landscape mode.
\ • User preference -- the app will switch orientation according to the global device settings.
\ • Device orientation -- follow the physical orientation of the device.
\ 
\ Keep device awake tells the application to keep the screen active until the user manually leaves the application. This is useful if you want to set Audalyzer up to continually display your sound level over a long period; however, be aware that it will quickly drain your battery.

Show performance stats tells Audalyzer to display certain performance statistics on-screen. These stats are updated every 5 seconds and include frames per second, computation time, drawing time, and the average time taken to perform frequency analysis (FFT) of a block of data.

string-array.name: help_info_texts
string-array.item: There is a discussion board where you can suggest ideas for Audalyzer, share experiences and thoughts with other users, and generally waffle. Please note that this group is shared with the other Moonblink projects, so mention Audalyzer when you post:\n\ \n\ • http://groups.google.com/group/moonblink/topics

If you want to report a bug, you can use the Moonblink Issue tracker. Before you post, please look through the existing issues -- including closed issues -- before raising a new one. Your problem may already have been solved.
\ 
\ If you do need to raise a new issue:
\ • The issue tracker is used by a number of projects. Please click on the "Product-" label to set the product you are reporting against. You can also set the other fields as appropriate.
\ • Please tell me what device, and what version of Android, you are using.
\ • If the bug is a crash, then please attach a log if you possibly can. If you don't know how, don't sweat it.
\ 
\ So, the issue tracker is here:
\ 
\ • http://code.google.com/p/moonblink/issues/list
Audalyzer is an open project, so if you want to join in and make contributions, you can. See the project page for information:\n\ \n\ • http://code.google.com/p/moonblink/wiki/Audalyzer
